A Cavalry Company was formed under the command of Capt. Joel W. Flood, becoming Co. H of the 2nd Va. Cavalry. A Company of Heavy Artillery was formed under Capt. James Robertson. A Company of Infantry under Capt. Thos. P. Mat thews, and another Company was formed under Capt. Wm. H. Abbitt, and quite a number of Appomattox citizens living near the rim of the county joined companies from adjoining coun ties. With hearts aflame and bodies dedicated to the Cause they held dear, they went to the front and shared the destiny of the heroes in Gray. Weakened by casualties, new calls came for volunteers, and long after the war, there was a scarcity of able bodied men in the County. Then came April 9, 1865, and the hand of destiny wrote finis across the scroll of four mighty years of struggle Destiny selected Appomattox for one of the major events oi history. Today there is hardly a town- or village in America, that has not heard of Appomattox. Thus ended in this Coun ty, one of the greatest Civil Wars ever chronicled in the files of Time, and at Appomattox began a new page in the history of America. Military rule was established shortly after April 9, 1865. Al county officers were replaced by military appointees. These were men who were selected upon the recommendation of the incumbents, and were willing to take the Iron Clad Oath. In the fall of 1866, an election was held under the Under wood Constitution, which put into effect the 13th and 14th Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, and a new slate of officers were named. Geo. T. Peers became Clerk Wm. T. Johnson Sheriff W. J. Collins, Commissioner of the Revenue the Office of County Treasurer was created Supervisors were provided for, and the ounty Government, practically as we have it now was estab lished. The ravages of four years of war were apparent, and Ap pomattox along with her sister counties, began to repair the wounds. The following years called forth the character and ability of her people, and the present institutions of our Coun- -y are but a tribute to their untiring labor and foresight. document.text: On Thursday, May 1, at 1230 p.m. the Appomattox Chapter of Retired Teachers met at the Parkway Restaurant for a luncheon and a subsequent program. There were thirty teachers present as well as several guests, including Mr. and Mrs. Paul Ghioto of the Appomattox Historical Park Area, Mrs. Thelma Spencer, President of District F and Mrs. AgeAes Rowhatham, both of Lynchburg, and Mrs. J. E. Anderson of Richmond. After the luncheon Mrs. Mildred OBrien Alvis, presi dent, called the meeting to order and after preliminaries introduced the speaker, Mr. Paul Ghioto, Historian of Appomattox Historical Park. He gave a most interesting, ehtertaining, and informative talk on the history of Appomattox County, present, past and future. He treated the subject under two heads Heritage, Festival, and Hori zons. He declared that Appo mattox County has quite a heritage, mentioning a number of families who have contribut ed so much to the history of Appomattox. He referred often to the book, History of Appomattox, written by Mr. N. R. Featherston quite a few years ago. He also called attention to the fact that the Appomattox and Buckingham Times as the paper was called then carried in an 1895 issue and article called the History of Surrender. He added that at one time soon after this article appeared that there was a request made that the name of the town Nebraska, as Appomattox was known at that time be changed to Surrender. Featherston, local histor ian, who plans a volume on Appo- mat.ox history, said this week leaving had Urgent  requests from several of my friends, I have decided to write a history of Ap pomattox County, or, it might be called a census, as I wish to have names of ell now living, or all those who lived in that part of Campbell, Charlotte, Buckingham or Prince Edward Counties which was form ed into Appomattox County in 1845. While 1 am very desirous of Having the ages of all in order to have the record as near complete as possible, if any object to having their ages published, of course, I will leave that blank. I fully realize this is a considerable undertaking, and will take lots of time and care, and I will have to depend upon the people to send me the information as to their families. I hope the people will cooperate and help me to get as complete a record of the county as possible. N. R . Featherston.
